title: 108_hr5319
content: The "Renewable Energy Financing Incentive Act of 2004" allows for nonrecognition of gain from the sale of real property upon subsequent purchase of renewable energy property under section 1046 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Renewable Energy Financing Incentive Act of 2004" allows for nonrecognition of gain from the sale of real property if the seller acquires renewable energy property within the replacement period. Gain resulting from the sale is only recognized to the extent that the price exceeds the cost of the renewable energy property acquired. The term 'renewable energy property' refers to facilities in the US using renewable energy sources for electricity generation or fuel production. Special rules apply to partnerships and corporations owning such property. Cooperatives are also included. The term 'replacement period' is defined. The term 'replacement period' refers to the 2-year period after the sale of real property with an election under subsection (a). Property must be identified within 180 days for it to be considered like-kind property. The basis of renewable energy property is the same as the exchanged property, adjusted for money received and gains or losses. If renewable energy property is disposed of, any gain must be recognized. The gain from the acquisition of renewable energy property is recognized to the extent not previously acknowledged. Certain dispositions, such as those after the taxpayer's death or for tax avoidance purposes, are not considered. A statute of limitations applies if gain is realized from the sale or exchange of renewable energy property with an election under subsection (a). The statute of limitations for assessing deficiencies related to gain from renewable energy property is extended to 3 years after the taxpayer notifies the Secretary of certain information. Assessments can be made within this 3-year period despite other laws preventing it. The statute of limitations for assessing deficiencies related to gain from renewable energy property is extended to 3 years after the taxpayer notifies the Secretary of certain information. Assessments can be made within this 3-year period despite other laws preventing it. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part III of subchapter O of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendments made by this section allow for nonrecognition of gain from the sale of real property upon subsequent purchase of renewable energy property, effective for real property sold after December 31, 2004.
